name: Riparian Corridor Vegetation (width/continuity)
functionStatement: Bank and floodplain processes shape channel planform and habitat complexity; balanced erosion and deposition support stability and ecological function.
descriptionMarkdown:
Percent forested land cover in the contributing watershed/catchment. Higher forest cover generally supports infiltration, reduces runoff and erosion, and can improve water quality.
Riparian corridor vegetation and continuity/width along the reach or contributing stream network. Healthy riparian vegetation supports shading, bank stability, and sediment/nutrient filtering.
methodContextMarkdown:
Context: Channel and Floodplain

Method: Field screening and/or Desktop (imagery)
howToMeasureMarkdown:
Delineate the contributing watershed and compute percent forest land cover using a land cover dataset (e.g., NLCD). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric.
Using recent imagery and/or land cover data, delineate the riparian corridor along the reach (or specified stream length) and quantify corridor width/continuity (e.g., percent of stream length meeting a minimum corridor width). Assign the condition class using the bin thresholds for this metric.

inputs.label: Riparian Corridor Vegetation (width/continuity)
inputs.helpMarkdown:
Land cover GIS (e.g., NLCD Land Cover or local land use/land cover dataset); watershed boundary.
Imagery
Recent aerial imagery (e.g., NAIP); land cover datasets (e.g., NLCD); hydrography/stream centerlines.

levels.label: Good
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Good: >80% of contributing streams (including tributaries) within catchment has > 25 feet corridor width. (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)

levels.label: Fair
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Fair: 50-80% of streams (including tributaries) within catchment has > 25 feet corridor width. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

levels.label: Poor
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Poor: <50% of streams (including tributaries) within catchment has > 25 feet corridor width. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.29)
